awd_titl_txt: GEM: Occurrence and Properties of Magnetic Reconnection in Magnetosheath Current Sheets
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic reconnection is a universal plasma process that converts stored magnetic energy into particle energies. The near-Earth space provides a natural laboratory this process can be studied in-situ.  This project builds on recent discoveries of reconnection in the Earth's magnetosheath of both non-turbulent and turbulent reconnection.  A comprehensive survey of data from the Cluster and Themis spacecraft in the magnetosheath will be carried out to establish the observational facts about magnetosheath reconnection.  These results will be used to address fundamental questions regarding onset, structure, heating and energization in reconnection as well as micro-scale reconnection in turbulent current sheets.  

The project involves training of one undergraduate and one graduate student and other educational and public outreach activities are planned as well. The database containing all the magnetosheath reconnection events will be made publicly available and will be useful for a broad range of other research projects on reconnection and on large current sheets in general.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetic reconnection is a fundamental universal energy conversion process that is important in space plasmas, including energy release in solar flares and auroral substorms. Reconnection converts stored magnetic energy into kinetic energy in the form of plasma jets and particle heating. We have used spacecraft observations in the shocked solar wind upstream of Earth to answer three outstanding questions concerning the onset conditions for reconnection, the controlling factors for particle heating in reconnection, and the structure of the reconnection jet (exhaust).

Our studies show that reconnection can be triggered in a current sheet when it is compressed against the magnetopause, i.e. when the current sheet becomes thin. We also deduced that the onset of reconnection also depends on the angle between the two reconnecting magnetic fields (magnetic shear) and the relationship between the plasma pressure and the magnetic pressure (plasma beta), with reconnection occurring preferentially for large magnetic shear and low plasma beta.

In addition we have demonstrated that the main controlling factor for both electron and ion heating in reconnection is the inflow Alfven speed. Specifically, the thermal energy gain per electron and ion is linearly proportional to the available magnetic energy per particle. We found that 1.7% of the available magnetic energy is converted into electron heating, and that 13% of the available magnetic energy is converted into ion heating. The ratio of ion to electron heating was found to be ~8 on average.

Finally, we found distinct asymmetries in the perpendicular and parallel ion temperature across the reconnection exhaust for symmetric reconnection with a large guide field. Also, the ion and electron temperature were enhanced on opposite sides of the exhaust. We demonstrated that the structure of large guide field reconnection is distinctly different from antiparallel reconnection.

Based on spacecraft observations in the near-Earth region this project has established general predictions for the reconnection process in terms of the onset, the amount of particle heating, and the exhaust structure. Thus the results from this project can be applied to reconnection in other astrophysical objects in regions not reachable by spacecraft.
